On a failed save, a creature takes 22 ([[/r 4d10]]) lightning damage, or 11 ([[/r 2d10]]) lightning damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage.

Greyshade Strangler.name: Greyshade Strangler
Greyshade Strangler.description:
Greyshade Strangler

Any adventurer worth their salt knows the rhyme “Grey and blue? Walk on through. Red and grey? Run away!” These bloodthirsty plants grow in dense patches, their thorny vines wrapped in coils ready to spring towards any creature with a heartbeat. There is never a safe path through a forest containing greyshade stranglers; with their diet of blood, they’ve no need for roots and can re- locate to new pastures whenever creatures learn to avoid their current hunting ground.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. Hit: 1 piercing damage and the greyshade strangler attaches to the target. Until removed, it moves with the target and can't attack another target.

A creature within 5 feet of the greyshade strangler can remove it by making a successful DC 8 Strength check. The greyshade strangler can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement.

False Appearance.name: False Appearance
False Appearance.description: If the swarm is motionless at the start of combat, it has advantage on its initiative roll. Moreover, if a creature hasn't observed the swarm move or act, that creature must succeed on a DC 13 Intelligence (Nature) check to discern that the swarm isn't an ordinary patch of plants.

Heartbeat Sense.name: Heartbeat Sense
Heartbeat Sense.description: The greyshade strangler knows the location of any creature with a heartbeat within 30 feet of itself.

Swarm of Broodlings.name: Swarm of Broodlings
Swarm of Broodlings.description: Subservient to their aboleth broodmothers, these ray-like amphibians scour the swamps they call home in search of creatures with high biomass or interesting features. Once a broodling has found an adequate target, it releases a pheromone, gathering its brethren and enhancing their hive-mind intellect. With their stings, the broodlings inject a toxin that makes their victim more suggestible, allowing them to use their augmented intelligence to submit the creature to their will. Once entranced, the creature follows the broodlings to the broodmother’s lair, where the matriarch decides how best to extract its assets.

Bites and Stings.name: Bites and Stings
Bites and Stings.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+5]]{+5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) piercing damage If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws until the end of the swarm's next turn.

Bites and Stings (Half Hit Points).name: Bites and Stings (Half Hit Points)
Bites and Stings (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+5]]{+5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws until the end of the swarm's next turn.

Mass Entrance.name: Mass Entrance
Mass Entrance.description:
The swarm targets any number of creatures it is aware of within 10 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be magically charmed by the swarm. A charmed target falls under the swarm's control and can't take reactions.

A charmed target can repeat the saving throw whenever it takes damage or whenever the swarm takes 15 or more damage in a single instance. On a success, the effect ends on it. No more than once every 24 hours, the target can also repeat the saving throw when it is 30 or more feet away from the swarm. The charm ends if the swarm dies or is on a different plane of existence from a charmed target.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The swarm can breathe air and water.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny broodling. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Swarm of Sun Jellies.name: Swarm of Sun Jellies
Swarm of Sun Jellies.description:
Sun Jelly

Sun jellies resemble their marine cousins in many ways, except they glow and swim through air instead of water. Their long tendrils of light trail lazily across the sky, void of a jellyfish’s typical sting. Benign and mindless, sun jellies will not harm other creatures unless truly agitated, and they are drawn to acts of kindness, self-sacrifice, and expressions of genuine vulnerability. A swarm gathered around a creature implies goodness and purity of heart, and the ability to attract such a bloom is a prerequisite for a Shai’tan squire to take their paladin oath.

Tendrils.name: Tendrils
Tendrils.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+3]]{+3} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 10 ([[/r 4d4]]) radiant damage

Tendrils (Half Hit Points).name: Tendrils (Half Hit Points)
Tendrils (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+3]]{+3} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 5 ([[/r 2d4]]) radiant damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Celestial Flare.name: Celestial Flare
Celestial Flare.description: The swarm glows with brilliant light, which has no effect on celestials or good creatures. Each other creature within 5 feet of the swarm must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 13 ([[/r 3d8]]) radiant damage. A creature that fails the save by 5 or more is also blinded until the end of the swarm's next turn.

Good Sense.name: Good Sense
Good Sense.description: The swarm knows the location of any good creatures within 30 feet of it.

Illumination.name: Illumination
Illumination.description: The swarm sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny sun jelly. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Swarm of Flying Magnetite Weapons.name: Swarm of Flying Magnetite Weapons
Swarm of Flying Magnetite Weapons.description:
Animated Magnetite

Crafted from highly magnetic magnetite, these animated objects share the common property of being immobilised by heat. An animated suit of plate armour is capable of conjuring bolts of arcanomagnetic force that can knock a creature off its feet. A swarm of animated weapons compounds the damage of its constituent parts with a devastating flurry of follow-up strikes.

Magnetite Weapons

Animated weapons are a common staple in a mage’s lair. In an instant, a well-stocked armoury transforms into a whirling flurry of flying swords, pikes, and hammers. The movement of the magnetic fields generates powerful bursts of lightning in the swarm’s epicentre, emitting forceful pulses that launch ferrous objects at deadly speeds. When whipped into an enormous swarm, their greater number allows them to redistribute the negative effects of heat to avoid complete immobilisation.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The swarm makes two Force Strikes attacks.

Force Strikes.name: Force Strikes
Force Strikes.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+6]]{+6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 18 ([[/r 4d8]]) force damage

Force Strikes (Half Hit Points).name: Force Strikes (Half Hit Points)
Force Strikes (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+6]]{+6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 ([[/r 2d8]]) force damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Supercharge.name: Supercharge
Supercharge.description: The swarm whirls and gathers lightning. Each creature within 10 feet of the swarm must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ([[/r 8d8]]) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Unattended ferrous objects are thrown 15 feet away from the swarm. If the object is being held or worn, the creature holding or wearing it must make a DC 14 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the object is thrown 15 feet away from the swarm.

Arcanomagnetic Repulsion.name: Arcanomagnetic Repulsion
Arcanomagnetic Repulsion.description: Attack rolls against the swarm made with ferrous weapons or ammunition are made at disadvantage.

False Object.name: False Object
False Object.description: If the swarm is motionless at the start of combat, it has advantage on its initiative roll. Moreover, if a creature hasn't observed the swarm move or act, that creature must succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence (Investigation) check to discern that the swarm isn't an ordinary pile of weapons.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Small weapon. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Superconductor.name: Superconductor
Superconductor.description:
If the swarm takes 10 or more fire damage in a single instance, its flying speed is reduced to 0 feet, it has disadvantage on attack rolls, and it can't use its Supercharge action.

These effects last until the end of the swarm's next turn.

Unusual Nature.name: Unusual Nature
Unusual Nature.description: The swarm doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Flight of Wyvnkin.name: Flight of Wyvnkin
Flight of Wyvnkin.description:
Wyvnkin

A wyvern’s young grows quickly after hatching. By two months of age, a wyvnkin looks much like its parents, bearing similar leathery wings, sharp teeth, razor claws, and a potent poison stinger. A wild wyvnkin ventures out of its nest by six months and is expected to fend for itself. If the hatchling hasn’t been tamed by this age, it remains forever feral.

Wyvnkin Flights. Though usually solitary creatures, some wyvnkin gather into collectives known as flights when making their homes in dangerous areas, such as the actively hostile environment of The Low or the territory of a deadlier predator. Unlike their parents, wyvnkin don’t shy away from ground battles thanks to their overwhelming numerical advantage. A multitude of tiny, looming shadows is often a sign of impending death by a swarm of dive-bombing draconic critters.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The flight makes one Bites and Claws attack, and one Stingers attack.

Bites and Claws.name: Bites and Claws
Bites and Claws.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+7]]{+7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) slashing damage, or 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) slashing damage if the flight has half of its hit points or fewer.

Stingers.name: Stingers
Stingers.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+7]]{+7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) piercing damage The target must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw, taking 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed save, a target is also poisoned for 1 minute, and it is blinded while poisoned in this way. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the poison on itself on a success.

Stingers (Half Hit Points).name: Stingers (Half Hit Points)
Stingers (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+7]]{+7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. The target must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw, taking 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed save, a target is also poisoned for 1 minute, and it is blinded while poisoned in this way. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the poison on itself on a success.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The flight can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the flight can move through any opening large enough for a Small wyvnkin. The flight can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Bites and Claws (Half Hit Points).name: Bites and Claws (Half Hit Points)
Bites and Claws (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+7]]{+7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) slashing damage, or 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) slashing damage if the flight has half of its hit points or fewer.

Thicket of Brambleweeds.name: Thicket of Brambleweeds
Thicket of Brambleweeds.description:
Brambleweeds were once exclusive to their native desert in the Wild Sands, where the scarcity of water kept the population in check. Traders passing through the area were instructed to check their caravans for errant brambleweeds carried by the wind, which would attach themselves to the bonnets of the wagons with their thorns. A few careless merchants were all it took to turn this dangerous plant into a widely spread invasive species. Now present in warm biomes across the world, brambleweeds can be recognized by their bulbous leaves and woody vines, covered in barb-like, raking thorns. Much like quicksand, the trick to surviving a fall into a patch of brambleweeds is remaining calm—the more one moves, the deeper the thorns dig into one’s flesh.

Overgrown Thickets. The introduction of bramble- weed into regions where water is more abundant has allowed them to thrive unchecked. A gallon of water can turn brambleweeds into a mobile thicket overnight, and a river can transform them into a village-wide threat. Culling brambleweeds is a dangerous but necessary task, one often assigned as punishment to disobedient druids and rangers.

Thorn Lashes.name: Thorn Lashes
Thorn Lashes.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+6]]{+6} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the thicket's space. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) bludgeoning damage if the thicket has half of its hit points or fewer, plus 7 ([[/r 3d4]]) piercing damage.

Wall Form.name: Wall Form
Wall Form.description:
The thicket arranges itself into an opaque wall of thorns that originates from one 5-foot space it currently occupies and extends out in a 5-foot-wide line that is up to 15 feet tall and up to 45 feet long. While in this form, a creature that attempts to move into or through the thicket's space for the first time on a turn must succeed on a DC 15 Strength check to do so; if the creature fails the check, its movement ends in the thicket's space and it become grappled by the thicket (escape DC 15).

The thicket reverts to its original form after 10 minutes, if it uses an action to do so, or if it dies. When the thicket reverts, it reforms in the space in the middle of the wall and ceases grappling creatures.

False Appearance.name: False Appearance
False Appearance.description: If the thicket is motionless at the start of combat, it has advantage on its initiative roll. Moreover, if a creature hasn't observed the swarm move or act, that creature must succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence (Nature) check to discern that the thicket isn't an ordinary patch of thorny plants.

Thorny Overgrowth.name: Thorny Overgrowth
Thorny Overgrowth.description: At the start of the thicket's turn, it deals 7 ([[/r 3d4]]) piercing damage to each creature in its space. Additionally, when a creature moves into or within the thicket's space, it takes 7 ([[/r 3d4]]) piercing damage for every 5 feet it moves.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The thicket can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the thicket can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny brambleweed. The thicket can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Thorn Lashes (Half Hit Points).name: Thorn Lashes (Half Hit Points)
Thorn Lashes (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+6]]{+6} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the thicket's space. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) bludgeoning damage if the thicket has half of its hit points or fewer, plus 7 ([[/r 3d4]]) piercing damage.

Death Shroud.name: Death Shroud
Death Shroud.description: A death shroud can be created by combining cloth imbued with necromantic energy with flesh free of a soul. One blast of biomantic energy later and you have an animate, cloth-wrapped limb. A death shroud actively recruits fresh corpses into its own form, temporarily increasing its size and strength. Over time, some of these additions stick, and the death shroud can grow to a mass of writhing limbs, heads, and torsos.

Slap.name: Slap
Slap.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+3]]{+3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 3 ([[/r 1d4 + 1]]) bludgeoning damage.

Lich Slap.name: Lich Slap
Lich Slap.description: Ranged Spell Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, range 30 ft., one creature. Hit: 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) necrotic damage and the target can't regain hit points until the start of the death shroud's next turn.

Morbid Curiosity.name: Morbid Curiosity
Morbid Curiosity.description: The death shroud is easily distracted by fresh corpses. Whenever it first detects a corpse that has been dead for less than 1 hour (and that it didn't witness die), it must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or get distracted. While distracted, it spends its movement and actions trying to get close to, and inspect, the corpse for a cause of death. A distracted death shroud in a corpse's space uses its action to make Intelligence (Medicine) checks (DC decided by the GM). On a success, it stops being distracted and becomes immune to the allure of that corpse forever.

Turn Immunity.name: Turn Immunity
Turn Immunity.description: The death shroud is immune to effects that turn undead.

Tool Proficiency.name: Tool Proficiency
Tool Proficiency.description:
The death's shroud has proficiency with thieves' tools.

Foundry Note: It's +3.

Swarm of Steel Darts.name: Swarm of Steel Darts
Swarm of Steel Darts.description:
Steel Dart

A byproduct of CRE’s misguided mechanical meddlings (see Forge of the Divine Machine in Motes of the Divine), steel darts are clockwork songbirds formed of hinged brass wings and steel that hides minuscule organs: a heart, tongue, stomach, lungs, and twitching vocal cords. A long, tapered beak allows steel darts to sup a meal of nectar and oil, keeping their hearts beating and their gears turning.

Songbirds. The frantic beating of one steel dart’s wings produces a steady drone over which it layers com- plex harmonies. When steel darts form swarms, however, they synchronise that gentle buzz into a single thunder- ous pitch that harmonically links their clockwork minds. One agitation of a steel dart quickly arouses the rest of the swarm and, with joined voices, the swarm’s song becomes a terrifying dirge of doom.

Beaks.name: Beaks
Beaks.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 10 ([[/r 4d4]]) piercing damage

Beaks (Half Hit Points).name: Beaks (Half Hit Points)
Beaks (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 5 ([[/r 2d4]]) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer, plus 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) thunder damage.

Force Weakness.name: Force Weakness
Force Weakness.description: When the swarm takes 6 or more force damage in a single instance, it must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, or it falls prone (temporarily overriding its condition immunity) and can take either an action or bonus action on its next turn, not both.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny steel dart. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Doom Song.name: Doom Song
Doom Song.description:
The swarm emits a terrifying song out to 30 feet.

Creatures in the area that hear the song must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of the swarm for 1 minute. A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the creature is immune to this swarm's Doom Song for the next 24 hours.

Storm of Brain Devourers.name: Storm of Brain Devourers
Storm of Brain Devourers.description:
Brain devourers are among the most gruesome denizens of The Low—wrinkled, grey brains supported by legs formed from twisted nerves. Seeing one instantly strikes fear into seasoned veterans, a delicious sentiment which is promptly drained by the hungry abomination. A single brain devourer can syphon the emotions of an entire city until its inhabitants are mindless husks.

Astral Transcendance. Brain devourers were once hu- manoids on a quest for cognitive transcendance. Gradual biomantic alterations ultimately caused them to shed all semblance of physical form, leaving only what they con- sider an intermediate step in humanoid evolution. Brain devourers believe the final step requires the consumption of a massive amount of brains, after which they will finally leave their bodies behind and ascend to the Astral Sea.

Ravenous Hordes. When a city’s guards prove too tough to crack, brain devourers are driven to form ferocious swarms by their voracious hunger. In a group, they trade subtlety for sheer numbers, and the resulting condensation of psychic energy manifests as a massive brain storm. To avoid this, mind flayers carefully manage brain devourer populations by feeding them periodically.

Dazing Touches.name: Dazing Touches
Dazing Touches.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+7]]{+7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) psychic damage, or 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) psychic damage if the storm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Mind Storm.name: Mind Storm
Mind Storm.description: The storm unleashes a wave of psychic energy. Each creature within 15 feet of the storm must make a DC 13 Intelligence saving throw, taking 27 ([[/r 6d8]]) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails the saving throw by 5 or more is also incapacitated until the end of the storm's next turn.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The storm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the storm can move through any opening large enough for a Small brain devourer. The storm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points except through its Consume Brain bonus action.

Consume Brain.name: Consume Brain
Consume Brain.description: The storm consumes the brain of one humanoid corpse in its space. It learns everything the humanoid knew in life and gains 20 temporary hit points. Until the start of its next turn, the storm has advantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws.

Swarm of Magnetite Cutlery.name: Swarm of Magnetite Cutlery
Swarm of Magnetite Cutlery.description:
Animated Magnetite

Crafted from highly magnetic magnetite, these animated objects share the common property of being immobilised by heat. An animated suit of plate armour is capable of conjuring bolts of arcanomagnetic force that can knock a creature off its feet. A swarm of animated weapons compounds the damage of its constituent parts with a devastating flurry of follow-up strikes.

Magnetite Cutlery

From the depths of the monastery dining rooms flies a swarm of steel knives, forks, spoons, and — most lethally — sporks. Such creatures can be animated by protective magics, or be under the direct control of a creature capa- ble of manipulating the arcanomagnetic spectrum, such as a magnetite dragon!

Jabs.name: Jabs
Jabs.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) piercing damage or 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Arcanomagnetic Repulsion.name: Arcanomagnetic Repulsion
Arcanomagnetic Repulsion.description: Attacks against the swarm made with ferrous weapons or ammunition are made at disadvantage.

Superconductor.name: Superconductor
Superconductor.description: If the swarm takes 10 or more fire damage in a single instance, it falls prone and, until the end of its next turn, it is incapacitated and its flying speed is reduced to 0 feet.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny utensil. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

Jabs (Half Hit Points).name: Jabs (Half Hit Points)
Jabs (Half Hit Points).description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) piercing damage or 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Spiketooth.name: Spiketooth
Spiketooth.description:
Spiketooth

These gentle, leathery creatures possess four stumpy legs, tiny blue eyes, and an oversized dermal horn that juts above a wide, overly-toothed maw. Despite what their shark-like rows of serrated teeth might imply, spiketooths aren’t carnivores. Their diet consists almost entirely of lichoozes; jelly-like symbioses between plants and oozes that grow on rock and bark in their native Shai’taryn.

Anthropology. While some families adopt spiketooths as pets, most councils throughout Shai’taryn outlaw the rearing of spiketooth herds, or ‘bristles’, as they are collectively known. Though spiketooths are not aggres- sive, fear can propagate amongst a bristle with alarming alacrity, resulting in a devastating stampede. The Shai’tan hold these creatures in high regard and, in academic cir- cles, scholars have long debated the plural of the creature; most prefer the term “spiketooths” for simplicity, but a fierce few cling to “spiketeeth.”

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 ([[/r 2d4 + 2]]) piercing damage.

Horn.name: Horn
Horn.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/r 1d20+4]]{+4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 ([[/r 1d6 + 2]]) piercing damage. If the spiketooth moved at least 20 feet straight toward the target immediately before the hit, the target takes an extra 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must then succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

Startleable.name: Startleable
Startleable.description: The spiketooth has disadvantage on saving throws made to avoid the frightened condition.
